Nagasaki's restored bell rings for first time in 80 years since atomic bomb
subhead: On Saturday, the two bells of Nagasaki's Immaculate Conception Cathedral rang together for the first time since 1945, when the United States dropped an atomic bomb on Nagasaki.

title: Firefighters battle to prevent reignition of France’s largest wildfire as residents return home
subhead: About 1,400 firefighters were deployed on Saturday in France's southern Aude region to prevent the country's largest wildfire in decades from reigniting, as all residents were allowed to return to their homes.

title: Israeli writer Etgar Keret: 'The war in Gaza must stop now'
subhead: 'We must do whatever is humanly possible to make' the war in Gaza 'stop,' the author implores in an op-ed for Le Monde. He calls for unity among 'politicians and artists, liberals and conservatives, religious and secular, Israelis and Europeans and Americans.'

title: Instagram: A 'digital cemetery' for Gaza Strip residents
subhead: On the social media platform, the accounts used by Palestinians to share their daily lives amid the waves of bombings reveal the human tragedy in the enclave, and have become sites for commemorations.

Ayn Rand's irresistible attraction to the dominance of the 'alpha male,' as embodied by Elon Musk
subhead: 'Musk Fictions' (6/6). Since 2024 and his opportunistic support for Donald Trump, American billionaire Elon Musk has increasingly cited the 20th-century novelist Ayn Rand, the apostle of rational selfishness and capitalism.

title: In France, suicide affects men three times more than women
subhead: With 13.4 deaths per 100,000 inhabitants, the suicide rate appears to have reached a 'floor' after several decades of decline. While the mental health of young people has drawn significant attention, it is older men who continue to be the most affected.

title: In rural France, young people keep the local tradition of partying alive
subhead: 'Why Do We Party?' (1/6). In eastern Rignieu-le-Désert, the Amicale Des Jeunes youth association upholds the tradition of local balls, a custom that in some places is now seen as a way of preserving local identity.
byline: By Camille Bordenet (Chazey-sur-Ain (eastern France), special correspondent)
